qas.question: What did Microsoft change the tablet resolution requirements on March 12, 2013?
Why did Microsoft decrease the required resoultion for tablets?

answers.text: to allow "greater design flexibility" for future products

qas.question: What is a convertible form factor?

answers.text: a standalone device that combines the PC, display and rechargeable power source with a mechanically attached keyboard and pointing device in a single chassis

qas.question: How does a convertible become a tablet?

answers.text: attached input devices are hidden or removed leaving the display as the only input mechanism

qas.question: What didn't Microsoft change the tablet resolution requirements on March 12, 2013?
What did Microsoft change the tablet resolution requirements on March 21, 2013?

plausible_answers.text: allow "greater design flexibility" for future products

qas.question: Why did Microsoft increase the required resoultion for tablets?

plausible_answers.text: a standalone device that combines the PC, display and rechargeable power source with a mechanically attached keyboard and pointing device in a single chassis

qas.question: What is an inconvertible form factor?

plausible_answers.text: attached input devices are hidden or removed leaving the display as the only input mechanism

qas.question: How does an inconvertible become a tablet?

context: Microsoft released minimum hardware requirements for tablet and laplet devices to be "certified" for Windows 8, and defined a convertible form factor as <a2_0><b7_0>a standalone device that combines the PC, display and rechargeable power source with a mechanically attached keyboard and pointing device in a single chassis<b7_0/><a2_0/>. A convertible can be transformed into a tablet where the <a3_0><b8_0>attached input devices are hidden or removed leaving the display as the only input mechanism<b8_0/><a3_0/>. On March 12, 2013, Microsoft amended its certification requirements to only require that screens on tablets have a minimum resolution of <a0_0><b4_0><b5_0>1024×768<b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/> (down from the previous 1366×768). The amended requirement is intended <a1_0>to <b6_0>allow "greater design flexibility" for future products<b6_0/><a1_0/>.
